title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement [INSERT CONTACT METHOD]. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.0, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/0/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Simulating Likert item responses in R
text: First, load package latent2likert, set seed reproducibility: generate size =10 responses n_levels = 5 response categories (5-point Likert scale), use: generate size =100 responses multiple Likert items different scales (example 4, 5 6), use: result array simulated responses, columns represent responses Likert items: corresponding bar plots shown :
code: # TODO: load the new package # library(latent2likert)  # set.seed(12345) setwd("/Users/markolalovic/dev/responsesR") source("./R/discretization.R") source("./R/simulation.R") source("./R/estimation.R") source("./R/utilities.R") rLikert(size = 10, n_levels = 5, n_items = 1) #>  [1] 3 5 4 3 3 2 2 3 4 4 data <- rLikert(size = 100, n_levels = c(4, 5, 6), n_items = 3) head(data) #>      Y1 Y2 Y3 #> [1,]  1  4  4 #> [2,]  2  5  5 #> [3,]  2  3  3 #> [4,]  2  5  6 #> [5,]  3  1  3 #> [6,]  2  2  1 par(mfrow=c(1, 3)) for(i in 1:3) {   barplot(table(data[, i]))   title(paste("Y", i, sep = "")) }

title: Simulating Likert item responses in R
text: set specific correlation latent variables, 0.5, set corr = 0.5: Alternatively, provide correlation matrix. instance, create 3 3 correlation matrix: , use generate responses Likert items latent correlation matrix R: use random correlation matrix, set R = "random":

title: Simulating Likert item responses in R
text: default, function rLikert generates symmetrically distributed responses. introduce asymmetry alter properties hypothetical survey respondents, adjust mean, standard deviation, skewness skew latent distribution.

title: Simulating Likert item responses in R
text: generate responses latent distributions different means, can set means using mu parameter. example, set means latent distributions -1, 0, 1, execute: generated responses corresponding densities latent distributions displayed .
code: data <- rLikert(size = 1000, n_levels = 5, n_items = 3, mean =c(-1, 0, 1)) par(mfrow=c(2, 3)) for(i in 1:3) {   barplot(table(data[, i]))   title(paste("Y", i, sep = "")) } x <- seq(-5, 5, length = 1000) y <- lapply(c(-1, 0, 1), function(mu) dnorm(x, mean = mu)) for(i in 1:3) {   plot(x, y[[i]], type="l", lwd = 2, xlab = "", ylab = "")   title(paste("X", i, sep = "")) }

title: Simulating Likert item responses in R
text: can adjust standard deviations latent distributions using sd parameter. instance, specifying sd = c(0.5, 1, 1.5): generates following responses corresponding densities latent distributions depicted :
code: data <- rLikert(size =1000, n_levels = 5, n_items = 3, sd = c(0.5, 1, 1.5)) par(mfrow=c(2, 3)) for(i in 1:3) {   barplot(table(data[, i]))   title(paste("Y", i, sep = "")) } y <- lapply(c(0.5, 1, 1.5), function(s) dnorm(x, sd = s)) for(i in 1:3) {   plot(x, y[[i]], type="l", lwd = 2, xlab = "", ylab = "")   title(paste("X", i, sep = "")) }

title: Simulating Likert item responses in R
text: can adjust skewness latent distributions using skew parameter. instance, specifying skew = c(-0.5, 0, 0.5) sets skewness latent distributions -0.5, 0, 0.5: resulting responses corresponding densities latent distributions displayed :  skew parameter controls skewness latent distribution. value skew limited slightly less interval (-1, 1): \[ -0.95 \leq \text{skew} \leq 0.95 \] positive value makes distribution right-skewed, negative value makes left-skewed.
code: data <- rLikert(size = 10^6, n_levels = 5, n_items = 3, skew = c(-0.5, 0, 0.5)) par(mfrow=c(2, 3)) for(i in 1:3) {   barplot(table(data[, i]))   title(paste("Y", i, sep = "")) } dp <- apply(cbind(rep(0, 3), rep(1, 3), c(-0.5, 0, 0.5)), 1,              function(x_row) { convert_params(as.vector(x_row)) }) x <- seq(-3, 3, length = 1000) y <- lapply(1:3, function(i) {    density_sn(x, dp[["xi", i]], dp[["omega", i]], dp[["alpha", i]])  }) for(i in 1:3) {   plot(x, y[[i]], type="l", lwd = 2, xlab = "", ylab = "")   title(paste("X", i, sep = "")) }

title: Simulating Likert item responses in R
text: order replicate existing survey data, can estimate parameters latent distributions using function estimate_parameters. illustration, let’s generate 1000 responses underlying normal distribution mean =-0.5 sd = 0.5, assuming n_levels = 5 response categories. Note possible categories may responses. example, n, mu, sd chosen responses value 5: addition responses, estimate_parameters function requires specifying number possible response categories K return estimates: can also provide responses multiple items. instance, generate responses three items different latent parameter values:
code: set.seed(12345) data <- rLikert(size = 1000, n_items = 1, mean = -0.5, sd = 0.5, n_levels = 5) table(data) #> data #>   1   2   3   4  #>  68 502 396  34 estimate_parameters(data, n_levels = 5) #>       mean         sd  #> -0.4629815  0.5008895 data <- rLikert(size = 1000,                 n_items = 3,                 mean = c(1, 2, 3),                 sd = c(0.5, 1, 1.5),                 n_levels = c(5, 6, 7)) par(mfrow=c(1, 3)) for(i in 1:3) {   barplot(table(data[, i]))   title(paste("Y", i, sep = "")) }

title: Converting Latent Variables Into Likert Scale Responses
text: package designed effectively simulate discretization process inherent Likert scales avoiding excessive distortion. converts continuous latent variables ordinal categories generate Likert scale item responses. particularly useful accurately modeling analyzing survey data use Likert scales, especially applying statistical techniques require metric data.

title: Converting Latent Variables Into Likert Scale Responses
text: development version can installed using devtools:

title: Converting Latent Variables Into Likert Scale Responses
text: rLikert: Generates random responses Likert scale questions based specified means standard deviations latent variables, optional settings skewness correlations. estimate_parameters: Estimates latent parameters existing survey data.

title: Converting Latent Variables Into Likert Scale Responses
text: keep package lightweight, latent2likert imports mvtnorm, along standard R packages stats graphics, typically included R releases. additional suggested dependency sn package, required generating random responses correlated Likert items based multivariate skew normal distribution. package prompts user install dependency interactive sessions needed.

title: rLikert — rLikert
text: Generates array random responses Likert-type questions based  specified latent variables.

title: rLikert — rLikert
code: rLikert(size, n_levels, n_items, mean = 0, sd = 1, skew = 0, corr = 0)

title: rLikert — rLikert
text: size: Integer. number observations (responses) generate. n_levels: Integer vector integers. number response categories  Likert scale item. Defaults 5. n_items: Integer. number Likert scale items (questions). Latent Variables Parameters mean: Numeric vector numerics. Means latent variables.  Defaults 0. sd: Numeric vector numerics. Standard deviations latent variables.  Defaults 1. skew: Numeric vector numerics. Marginal skewness latent variables.  Defaults 0. corr: Numeric correlation matrix. Correlations latent variables.  Can single numeric value representing correlation pairs,  "random" random correlation matrix, actual correlation matrix.  Defaults 0.

title: latent2likert 0.1.0 (Release date: 2020-10-17)
text: Initial release. Tested platforms: x86_64-pc-linux-gnu (64-bit) x86_64-w64-mingw32 (64-bit).

title: latent2likert 1.0.0 (Release date: 2024-03-28)
text: option generate correlated Likert scale items added function rLikert(). New function estimate_parameters() added allows estimation parameters existing survey data replicate accurately. Issues related dependencies resolved. version now imports mvtnorm, along standard R packages stats graphics, typically included R releases. additional suggested dependency package sn, necessary generating correlated responses based skew normal distribution. However, package prompts user install dependency interactive sessions.

title: latent2likert 1.1.0 (Release date: 2024-06-06)
text: minor update functions vignettes.

title: latent2likert 1.1.1 (Release date: 2024-06-06)
text: package renamed responsesR latent2likert. capture essence converting latent variables Likert scale responses. Improvements package website documentation.

title: latent2likert 1.2.1 (Release date: 2024-06-12)
text: codebase currently development, finer details may change. Refactored modular code tested . Improved error handling different cases correlations input. Better names functions arguments. Updated reference documentation.
